awd_titl_txt: Nucleation of Manganese Oxides in the Presence of Reactive Halogen Species
awd_abstract_narration:
Funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Professor Young-Shin Jun at Washington University examines the formation of manganese oxide particles in salt water. Manganese oxides are environmentally abundant and are important in removing contaminants. Their formation can be affected by products from human activities that have high salt concentrations, such as from desalination and oil and gas recovery. The chemical reactions involved are poorly understood, including the roles of halide ions (e.g., chloride and bromide) and highly reactive halogen species. This work quantitatively and qualitatively examines how salt water chemistry affects the formation of manganese oxides in the environment. The project also develops environmental chemistry outreach programs for underrepresented or economically disadvantaged K-12 students. This outreach both encourages the early involvement of high school and undergraduate students in research and improves university courses by incorporating research outcomes.

The increased production of highly saline effluents from water and energy generating processes raises questions about their impacts on the environment. In particular, halides in brine can greatly affect mineral formation and dissolution processes in natural aquatic systems. With sunlight, halides may further undergo photochemical reaction to generate reactive radical species. However, the effects of halides under sunlight exposure on redox-active transition metal ions and their solid phase formation are still obscure. This project investigates the effects of reactive halogen species on the oxidation of aqueous manganese (Mn) ions and the kinetics of the nucleation and growth of Mn particles, with and without natural organic matter. It is hypothesized that reactive species generated from reactions between natural organic matter and halides during their photolysis can promote the photochemical oxidation of Mn2+ (aq) and facilitate the formation of higher oxidation states of manganese oxides. To elucidate the properties of newly formed manganese oxides and to examine these dynamic redox reaction behaviors, solid phases of manganese oxides and fluid chemistries are characterized. In situ synchrotron-based small angle x-ray scattering provides real-time information about the nucleation and growth of manganese oxides. The project advances fundamental knowledge regarding the nucleation mechanisms and kinetics of manganese oxides in highly saline systems, which is important for predicting contaminant removal and transport and for developing new manganese-based materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nucleation of Manganese Oxides in the Presence of Reactive Halogen Species. Prof. Young-Shin Jun received an NSF grant (CHE-1905077) to investigate fast abiotic Mn oxidation from Mn2+ to Mn(IV) by reactive halogen species (RHS) in sunlight.

To meet clean water and energy demands, desalination and unconventional oil and gas recovery have been exploited, both bringing highly concentrated brine to the surface. With sunlight, the halides involved can undergo further photochemical reaction to generate RHS. The project investigated the effects of RHS on the oxidation of Mn (aq) and the kinetics of Mn oxide nucleation and growth, and has determined the reactions between halides and different ROS in the presence of Mn2+(aq).

Intellectual Merit: The redox chemistry of manganese significantly affects the biogeochemical cycling of metal and organic carbon and the fate of contaminants and nutrients in aqueous systems. While oxidation from Mn2+(aq) to MnIVO2 solid has been considered to occur mostly in microbially-promoted systems, abiotic Mn oxidation processes have been overlooked. This project provides novel fundamental information about photochemically-induced Mn oxidation and the formation of nanophase MnO2 solid in the presence of RHS in abiotic systems. Key accomplishments of this project include:

(1)     Revealing an unexpected mechanism that generates secondary ROO peroxyl radicals from reactions between a commonly used radical scavenger, tert-butyl alcohol, and hydroxyl radicals

(2)     Discovering that RHS generated by the photochemical reactions between halides and hydroxyl radicals can facilitate the inorganic oxidation of aqueous Mn2+(aq) into MnIV oxide solids

(3)     Elucidating the co-effects of DOM and halides on the generation of ROS and RHS and their photochemical oxidation of Mn2+(aq) and subsequent MnIV oxide formation

(4)     Introducing a new paradigm for the direct formation of todorokite in nature (under low temperature, low pressure, and circumneutral pH). Mg2+ is incorporated at the corner of a tunnel structure of todorokite.

(5)     Inspiring highly conductive Mn oxide nanosheet formation. Co incorporation influences the concentration of oxygen vacancies, the band gap, the activation energy, and increases the conductivity of Mn oxide nanosheets.

These findings help fill knowledge gaps about the abiotic natural formation mechanism and material properties of Mn oxides in the presence of reactive radicals (both reactive oxygen species and reactive halogen species). This knowledge is critical for comprehending the behavior and occurrence of natural Mn oxides, as well as their potential applications in environmental remediation and clean energy technologies.

This project has resulted in one doctoral dissertation. The project outcomes were disseminated via eight journal articles, with four more papers currently in review, and 11 invited and 14 contributed presentations at universities and conferences. To conduct the research, we made successful proposals for nine synchrotron-based X-ray beamtime allocations at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory, IL.

Broader Impacts: The project team have worked with Washington University's Institute for School Partnership and College Prep program to offer an "Environmental Chemistry and Nanoparticles" program for high school students. The project team also offered outreach hands-on workshops to Black middle school students and teachers from BrightPath STEAM Academy, which helps remedy critical educational gaps that impact African American middle school students. The research findings were incorporated into Aquatic Chemistry classes as examples of metal complexation, dissolution and precipitation, and redox chemistry and into Environmental Nanochemistry classes as examples of reactive radicals and 2D nanosheets and their electronic and physicochemical properties. The project has supported five doctoral students, two master's degree students, and six undergraduate researchers (one woman and two African Americans) in the PI's lab. All of these students gained hands-on wet lab experience studying RHS radical formation and Mn chemistry, and they received numerous awards and honors based on their findings in this project. Doctoral students involved in this project have successfully developed their careers and now they are working at Intel, Princeton University, and the University of Chicago. One doctoral student became an assistant professor at Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China.
